I saw a weary way-worn man — whose form</br>Was bent and bow'd with toil and crook'd with age;</br>Like an old oak he stood — on which the storm</br>Of many a year had bent its fiercest rage;—</br>Nor still unscath'd stood he — his pilgrimage</br>Was long — and slowly tottering on he came,</br>Alone and desolate! . . . The world's wide stage</br>Had nought of pleasure left for him, and fame</br>Told not his warlike deeds nor did his works proclaim.

Friendless was he — unpitied and unknown—</br>Fall all his race and kindred long were dead;—</br>And he was left forsaken and alone,</br>To beg a shelter for his houseless head!</br>Yes!  he who in his country's cause had bled</br>And nerv'd his arm for right and Liberty—</br>He — now went houseless — all his joys were fled—</br>Poor, comfortless, despised — in misery—</br>Without one breast, for all his wretchedness to sigh.

He paused awhile — and with an uprais'd glance</br>He gazed intent on every form that pass'd,</br>The young — the middle aged — the old — that chance</br>Had hap'd to bring that way: — and each one cast</br>A cold unfriendly look at him — then fast</br>Retreating, left him standing lonely there.</br>This was too much! — he'd borne the wintry blast,</br>The midnight storm — without a sigh or tear—</br>But, O, such cold indifference he could not bear.

I saw the tear steal from his aged eye—</br>I saw him dash it hastily aside—</br>He bore his many suffering manfully,</br>And scorn'd to murmur in his veteran pride.</br>The old man went his way — nor friend nor guide</br>Led him through regions all unknown. — His way</br>Was dark — his wants by none supplied—</br>Nor murmur'd he, tho' not one single ray</br>Broke the deep gloom through which he pass'd to brighter day.

I turn'd away in sorrow, "And is this,"</br>I cried, "the hardy veteran's only meed?</br>Must he who pav'd the way to our own bliss,</br>Be thus condemn'd to penury and need?"</br>No!  Heaven forbids!  by mercy 'tis decreed</br>That some extended arm, tho' late should save</br>From misery, want, and wo — those men who freed</br>Their soil and country from perdition's wave,</br>Nor suffer them to sink forgotten to the grave.</br>
